properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa, including Kialla
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa, including Kialla and replaces the warning issued at 11:43am Thursday.

Minor flooding is possible at Kialla West from Friday Afternoon as a flood peak moves from Euroa. The Seven Creeks peaked at Euroa around 4am Thursday morning.  

In the 24 hours to 9:00am Thursday, rainfall totals of up to 50 millimetres were recorded in the Seven Creeks catchment and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Seven Creeks downstream of Euroa:
The Seven Creeks at Kialla West is currently at 1.83 metres and steady. 
The Seven Creeks at Kialla West may exceed the minor flood level of 4.5 metres Friday afternoon. 
The river level may peak near 4.60 metres Friday evening.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert. Never enter floodwater. Deciding to drive into floodwater may be the last decision you make. 
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

  • Check your Local Flood Guide on the SES website for likely local impacts and advice on how to prepare: www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council

  • Understand what different flood levels mean for your neighbourhood and your property using the Goulburn Broken Community Flood Intelligence Portal at: https://www.gbcma.vic.gov.au/our-region/waterway-floodplain-management/floodplain-planning/gbfloodintelligenceportal

Impacts in your area: 
  • Mitchell Road is likely to flood between Seymour Road / Goulburn Valley Highway and Archer Street. 
  • Expect to see high river levels and local roads flooding in areas close to the Seven Creeks.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 05/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Tawonga, Mount Beauty and District. 

  • Severe storms occurred Wednesday Night with several properties and roads impacted by fallen trees and storm debris. 

  • Several roads remain closed due to unsafe storm damage and debris, including Tawonga Gap Road, Mountain Creek Rorad, Damms Road, Ronald Street and Maddisons Lane. 

  • Emergency services will continue to work in the area on Friday to clear and assess roads and dangerous trees. 

Do not cycle or drive on closed roads. Dangerous trees can kill. If you still require emergency storm help, call SES on 132 500. 

This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this incident. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang
properties.webBody:
Flood Warning Number: 12

MINOR FLOODING CONTINUES AT LODDON WEIR

River level rises have been observed across the Loddon River catchment in response to rainfall during the last week. 

River levels are now generally easing but remain above the minor flood level at Loddon Weir.

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Thursday, scattered rainfall totals of up to about 10 mm were recorded in the Loddon River catchment. 

The chance of showers and possible thunderstorm activity remains during Thursday but rainfall totals are not expected to significantly affect river levels.

Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang:
    Minor flooding is occurring at Loddon Weir. Flooding is not expected to extend downstream to Appin South or Kerang.
      The Loddon River at Appin South is currently at 2.51 metres and falling slowly, below the minor flood level (2.80 m). 

      The Loddon River at Appin South is expected to remain below the minor flood level (2.80 m).
      Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
      What you should do: 

      • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
      • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
      • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
      • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
      Impacts in your area: 

      • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
      • Check VicTraffic for road closures and always follow instructions from emergency services.
      This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

      The next update is expected by 05/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

      Use multiple sources to stay informed:
      • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
      • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
      • VicEmergency app
      • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
      • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

      Accessibility: 
      The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
      • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
      • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This message is being issued for Warrenbayne, Swanpool and District. 

  • Severe storms occurred Wednesday Evening with several properties and roads impacted by fallen trees and other storm debris. 
  • Some local roads may have active traffic management for some time while council works to fully clear and reopen roads. 
Exercise caution on the roads and minimise unnecessary travel until all roads are reopened.  
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this incident.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Poowong, Loch and Nyora residents. 
  • The tap water in Poowong, Loch and Nyora is not safe to drink without boiling first. 
  • A boil water advisory has been issued following reports of contaminated water in the Poowong-Loch-Nyora water supply system.
  • Consumption of unboiled water can cause gastro-like symptoms. If you experience any of these symptoms, please contact your GP and inform your GP of this advisory.
If you live or work within Poowong, Loch and Nyora, you must boil tap water before drinking. Or drink bottled water.
What you should do:  
  • Boil water before drinking it, or drink bottled water.  
  • Boil water for washing and preparing food, preparing beverages, making ice and for preparing baby formula. 
  • Boil water for brushing teeth.
To ensure water is safe to drink you should: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable, variable temperature kettles should be set to boil).
  • Allow water to cool before use.
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
  • Be careful when boiling water to prevent scalding or burns. 
It is safe to use unboiled water for:
  • Washing your hands
  • Cleaning dishes - use hot soapy water and let them air dry before using them again or use a dishwasher. 
  • Washing clothes.
  • Showering and bathing in. Young children should be given a sponge bath to avoid them accidentally swallowing the water. 
  • Garden watering. If you grow fruits and vegetables then they will need to be washed with cooled boiled water before you eat them.
  • Flushing toilets.
For health advice:
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.
Impacts in your area: 
  • South Gippsland Water advises customers in Poowong, Loch and Nyora to boil their drinking water until further notice. 
  • Water trailers are available at Nyora Recreational Reserve, Poowong Recreational Reserve, Main Street Loch and Speight Street in Loch from 9:30 am on 04/01/2024.
  • Further details can be found at https://www.sgwater.com.au/alerts
This message was issued by Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 05/01/2024 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 07/01/2024 06:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Avoca River to Charlton Town.

MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT CHARLTON TOWN FROM LATE THURSDAY AFTERNOON, WITH PEAK POSSIBLE OVERNIGHT THURSDAY INTO FRIDAY

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Wednesday, rainfall totals of up to 10-20 mm were recorded in the Avoca River catchment, with no significant rainfall since then. 

This has caused renewed river level rises along the Avoca River. 

The chance of showers and thunderstorm activity is forecast for Thursday, but rainfall totals are not expected to significantly affect river levels.

Avoca River to Charlton Town:
Minor flooding may occur along the Avoca River to Charlton Town. 

A below minor flood peak was observed early Thursday morning at Yawong Weir, with the peak now travelling toward Charlton Township.

The Avoca River at Charlton Township is currently at 3.67 metres and steady, below the minor flood level(4.00 m). 

The Avoca River at Charlton Township is likely to reach the minor flood level (4.00 m) from late Thursday afternoon. 

The river level may peak near 4.40 metres overnight Thursday into Friday, with minor flooding.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 05/01/2024 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Barraport West, Boort, Catumnal, Glenloth East, Lake Marmal, Nareewillock, Terrappee, Wychitella North .

  • There is a haystack fire near the  Quambatook-Wychitella Rd, Lake Marmal. 
  • Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities as firefighters pull apart the hay to extinguish the fire. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to cal VicEmergency
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

  •  Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 09/01/2024 10:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
